What we're talking about here is taking a nice controlled pace to our exercises

Now there's a few key reasons for this. The first one is that most people who are new to strength training
Or not particularly experienced with it tend to move a little bit fast when we move fast
We miss out on a few key things
Momentum takes away your ability to produce force
So while momentum is a fundamental part of human movement

So moving slow allows you to remove the momentum pace
Second part about it is that it's going to help to condition your connective tissues
So your tendons and ligaments they are going to stay under load consistently throughout the entire repetition

Sometimes that's the first time we've done such an exercise
We need time to practice that exercise and awareness in order to get better at it

So moving that little bit slower in your lifting is going to help you to develop better body awareness
Second thing I want to talk to you about is using a full range of motion in your exercises
So what does this mean? Well range of motion just refers to
How much of a particular joint we're expressing when we do an exercise
So as an example if I'm doing an overhead press with my shoulder
This here might be considered a limited range of motion whereas this here might be considered
Full range of motion. I'm opening that shoulder as far as I can into the overhead position
And then I'm bringing it all the way down now. Why is it important for you to express full range of motion in your training?
There's a few reasons for this your joints
Are going to become stronger by doing so because you're taking that joint from a completely closed to a completely open position
So if we think about that in terms of degrees you're expressing the most amount of degrees you can
So your joints become stronger the second part of that is that you're actually hitting more muscle in each repetition
Now that you're expressing the maximal amount of range in that joint
You are hitting your muscle through that full range. So that means that we get
Stronger as a result of that exercise the third part
Is simply that you now make more gains from the same amount of input. So think of it this way
If I'm performing three sets of ten of an overhead press limited range like this

If we're saying that each repetition on day two was perhaps ten to twenty percent more range than the day before
I'm now doing ten to twenty percent more work

It's also going to help you to increase your mobility
